reinforcements.similarity: Both address the critical gap between human-mediated trust and platform-mediated experience. Library works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) prescribes that the platform must feel like a continuation of the phone call. New works-001 (Resolve Product-Category Miscommunication Before Evaluation Begins) prescribes that the product category must be communicated at every touchpoint before evaluation. Both identify the phone call as the current primary mechanism for resolving fundamental comprehension gaps that the platform fails to address.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas's call ends with human-to-human promises and zero platform mention; the host's first digital encounter is unprimed. New evidence: Taline's call reveals that a guest arriving from Craigslist has zero understanding of the product category and requires 3+ minutes of human conversation to learn it. Both demonstrate the same structural weakness from opposite sides of the marketplace: the platform delegates foundational comprehension to human agents rather than resolving it at the first digital touchpoint. The d.school book's observation that 'this story starts with a miscommunication' (line 89) and Kahneman's priming research converge on the same principle: the first impression must establish the correct frame.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address pricing opacity as the single most critical information gap in the platform. Library communicates-002 (Single-Sum Financial Display) prescribes showing one total in the user's native format before any breakdown, established from the host side. New works-003 (Surface Indicative Pricing Before Agent Mediation) prescribes showing price ranges and estimates at every stage from the guest side. Both identify that users think in monthly totals, not nightly rates, and that the absence of any price signal is worse than an imprecise one.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas processes pricing as a sequential additive sum ('first month... broker's fee? One month. Three months. Okay. Got it,' andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16). New evidence: Taline asks 'So I just want to know how much would it cost' (2:51) and receives no answer. Bryant admits 'I have sort of a general idea, but not exact' (5:33). The Kahneman bat-and-ball research (library) and the d.school experiential learning principle (new) converge: users need a number to work with, and the format must match their mental model. This reinforcement elevates the pricing transparency principle to a universal platform rule validated from both marketplace sides.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address how proposals and post-interaction state should be structured. Library communicates-005 (Pre-Packaged Proposal) prescribes presenting proposals as confirmable packages for the host. New communicates-004 (Post-Call Summary as Structured Information Artifact) prescribes generating a structured summary for the guest after every substantive interaction. Both identify that the post-interaction state must be persistent, structured, and actionable rather than ephemeral and verbal.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Bryant presents tenant arrangements as pre-packaged deals the host can confirm. New evidence: Taline's call ends with zero written record, zero status visibility, and an unstructured 'feel free to text me' (6:13-6:20). Both Kahneman's System 1 endorsement principle and the d.school's 'what exactly just happened' reflection principle converge: post-interaction artifacts reduce cognitive load and maintain engagement. The combined insight: proposals must be optimized for BOTH sides -- easy to accept for the host AND transparent in progress for the guest.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the speed gap between human conversation and platform interaction. Library works-003 (Match the Platform's Cognitive Speed to the Phone Call's Conversational Speed) prescribes that platform interactions must match or exceed the efficiency of phone conversation. New works-002 (Enable Guest Self-Adaptation with Structured Alternatives) prescribes that the platform must replicate the human agent's ability to suggest alternatives in real time. Both identify that the phone call achieves outcomes (comprehension, adaptation, pricing) that the platform currently cannot, and that the platform must close this capability gap.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas describes two units in 7 seconds; the platform must match this density. New evidence: Taline adapts from full-time to M-F in under 60 seconds, but only because Bryant suggested 'five nights a week' (3:21) as a specific alternative. Both use the same benchmark: the phone call is the standard of efficiency and responsiveness. The combined insight: the platform must compete not just on speed of data entry (host side) but on speed of alternative generation (guest side).

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that the first information element on every screen must be something the user already knows or that immediately orients them. Library communicates-001 (Anchor-Then-Advance) prescribes opening every host screen with the host's own data. New communicates-001 (Product-Category Label Before Any Detail) prescribes that the product category must be the first piece of information on every guest-facing surface. Both establish the principle that recognition precedes comprehension: the user must see something familiar before processing anything new.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Kahneman's associative coherence principle -- showing the host their own data activates their existing associative network. New evidence: Taline's first question ('is it for a certain time?', 0:52) reveals zero orientation. The d.school's finding that 'what the students thought might be the need and what they actually found turned out to be two very different things' (line 86). Both approaches share the same cognitive principle (anchor first, advance second) but apply it to different user types: hosts need to see their own data; guests need to see the product category.

contradictions.conflict: Library communicates-006 (Agent Continuity Frame) prescribes that the platform must attribute all communications to the human agent, maintaining the human-mediated frame. New communicates-006 (Stay Pattern as Interactive Visual Before Text) prescribes replacing verbal/textual model explanation with an interactive visual calendar -- a fundamentally self-service, non-agent-mediated interaction. The tension is: the library says the platform should feel like 'Bryant's tool,' while the new element says the platform should replace what Bryant does verbally with a self-service visual component.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library evidence is strong for host-side trust (Andreas expects to deal with Bryant, not a website). The new evidence is equally strong for guest-side comprehension (Bryant's 45-second verbal explanation failed to establish comprehension; a visual calendar would succeed in 3 seconds). The contradiction is contextual rather than fundamental: agent attribution serves trust on the host side; self-service comprehension serves efficiency on the guest side. They can coexist if the visual calendar is presented as something 'your agent prepared' rather than as a platform-generated widget.
contradictions.recommendation: Design the interactive calendar component to carry agent attribution when accessed from agent-mediated flows, and to stand alone when accessed from self-service flows. The agent frame is not inherently incompatible with self-service tools; it requires that self-service tools are introduced by the agent rather than replacing the agent.

extensions.gap_filled: Post-interaction momentum and self-service progress tracking for guests. The library has no element addressing what happens between a guest's first interaction and their receipt of a proposal. This is the highest-risk dropout gap in the guest journey: Taline was left with zero status visibility, zero self-service path, and an unstructured promise of a callback.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Taline + d.school). The pattern is strong from this one case but needs validation from additional guest calls to confirm that the post-call void is universal rather than specific to Craigslist-sourced guests.

extensions.gap_filled: Life-context data capture and proactive matching. The library has no element addressing how the platform captures and uses non-housing data (commute constraints, childcare schedules, secondary jobs, family fallback locations) to improve matching quality. This is entirely new territory: the library treats listing evaluation as property-centric, while this element proposes life-centric evaluation.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Taline's case is compelling because her life constraints (son's school, two jobs, mother's house) are the actual decision drivers, not the property features. But this needs validation from additional guest calls to determine how common complex life-context constraints are among Split Lease guests.

extensions.gap_filled: Negotiation as supported exploration rather than adversarial interaction. The library has no element addressing how the guest negotiation experience should be designed. The host library covers proposal presentation (communicates-005: Pre-Packaged Proposal) but from the host's confirmation perspective only. This element addresses the guest's emotional and functional experience of encountering a mismatch and finding an alternative.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The negotiation dynamic observed (rejection -> self-rescue -> adaptation) is specific to Taline's call but likely representative of any guest whose initial need does not match the platform model. Needs validation from guest calls where the mismatch was handled differently.

extensions.gap_filled: Category comprehension gating for first-time guests. The library addresses phase-transition trust gates for hosts (works-001: System 1 Trust Gate) but has no equivalent for the foundational guest comprehension gate: ensuring the guest understands the product category before engaging with any platform feature. This is a guest-specific interaction pattern with no host-side equivalent.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but supported by strong evidence. Taline's entire journey was shaped by a category misunderstanding that persisted through 3 minutes of phone conversation. The d.school's observation about expectation-reality gaps adds theoretical weight. High confidence this pattern generalizes to most first-time guests.

extensions.gap_filled: Interactive stay pattern builder with live cost feedback. The library has no element addressing how the guest configures their stay pattern or receives pricing feedback in real time. This is the single most important self-service interaction for the guest side: it replaces both the verbal model explanation (45 seconds of failed comprehension) and the pricing conversation ('how much does it cost?' with no answer) with a single interactive component.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but the evidence is strong from both the call and the book. Taline understood the model only when Bryant offered a specific, concrete pattern ('five nights a week,' 3:21). The d.school's experiential learning principle directly supports interactive manipulation over textual explanation. High confidence this pattern is critical for guest conversion.

extensions.gap_filled: Emotional design for confused newcomers at discovery. The library has no feels-layer elements at all -- this entire layer is new territory. The first emotional element addresses the specific feeling of disorientation a guest experiences when encountering an unfamiliar product category under time pressure.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The emotional arc observed in Taline's call (confusion -> urgency -> deflation -> adaptation -> tentative hope -> anxiety) is specific to her situation but the discovery-phase disorientation is likely universal for guests encountering Split Lease for the first time.

extensions.gap_filled: Dignity-preserving redirect at rejection moments. No library element addresses how the platform should handle the emotional impact of telling a guest their need cannot be met. This element establishes the principle that constraint and alternative must appear as a single perceptual unit, with the alternative as the emotionally dominant signal.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Taline's emotional disclosure during the rejection moment (childcare logistics, financial stress, family dynamics) is compelling evidence that rejection moments extract emotional labor from guests. The d.school's 'soft on people' principle provides theoretical grounding. Moderate-to-high confidence.

extensions.gap_filled: Interactive stay pattern calendar as a visual component. The library has no looks-layer elements -- all visual patterns are new territory. This element defines the signature visual component for the Split Lease model: a 7-day row calendar with tappable night blocks and live cost feedback.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The visual specification is derived from Taline's comprehension failure with verbal explanation and success with a concrete numeric pattern. The d.school's experiential learning principle supports the interactive visual approach. The specific token usage and contrast ratios are well-grounded in the existing design system. High confidence this component is necessary.

extensions.gap_filled: Mismatch-to-alternative bridge card visual pattern. No library element defines the visual pattern for presenting constraint-plus-alternative as a single visual unit. This element specifies the three-layer card (acknowledgment, constraint, alternative) with warm amber for the constraint and trust green for the alternative.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The visual pattern directly maps to the interaction pattern (behaves-003) and the emotional principle (feels-002). The token usage is consistent with the existing system. Moderate confidence -- needs validation that the warm-amber-to-green visual language is perceived as supportive rather than alarming by real users.

new_tokens_flagged: price-confirmed-bg (suggested: accent-light #e8f0eb -- may need semantic alias)
token_compliance.recommendation: Most flagged tokens are component-specific sizing and animation tokens that extend the existing system without conflicting with it. The color tokens (badge-calendar-fill, badge-calendar-active, calendar-active-hover, price-confirmed-bg) all reference existing palette values (accent, accent-light, accent-bright) and should be added as semantic aliases rather than new primitives. The animation tokens (price-transition-duration, bridge-card-transition, layout-transition-duration) introduce durations not currently in tokens.json; consider adding a 'durations' section to tokens.json with standard values (200ms, 300ms, 400ms). The logic token (commute-threshold-warn: 30 minutes) is a design decision, not a visual token, and should live in a configuration file rather than the token system.

journey_emotion_map.rationale: Guest arrives confused and urgent. The target is calm orientation -- resolving the category misunderstanding before any other emotion can build.
Guest is searching in a noisy external system (Craigslist) with misaligned criteria. Relief comes from the platform making essential information (availability, cost, commute) immediately visible.

Guest encounters the mismatch moment (full-time rejected). Relief from the simultaneous alternative. Confidence from the interactive pricing calculator that puts her in control of the cost exploration.

Guest adapts her needs. Momentum from the adaptation being framed as a discovery (gain), not a compromise (loss). Confidence from social proof and cost savings displayed alongside the adapted pattern.
Guest enters the post-call void. Safety from the structured status tracker, specific timelines, and proactive updates that make the wait visible and bounded.
Guest receives a confirmed proposal. Safety from seeing her details accurately captured. Confidence from the confirmed price replacing the estimate with clear labeling.

Guest's complex weekly logistics (commute, son's school, weekend transitions) must be accommodated. Safety from the platform demonstrating it understands her life complexity through commute data and pattern-aware messaging.

Guest has zero margin for error (two jobs, child's school, rigid M-F pattern). Safety from proactive schedule support. Relief from the platform acknowledging her life complexity rather than treating her as a generic booking.

arc_conflicts: The emotional arc has a potential gap between the confidence of negotiation/pricing exploration and the safety of the post-call void. If the guest experiences empowerment during the interactive pricing phase and then is released into an unstructured wait with no self-service path, the emotional drop is steep. The status tracker (feels-004) is designed to bridge this gap, but if the tracker is delayed or the SLA is not met, the guest experiences the sharpest emotional drop in the entire journey.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc makes sense end-to-end for a guest journey that begins with confusion and urgency. The progression from calm (discovery) through relief and confidence (evaluation/negotiation) to safety (proposal/active lease) follows a coherent pattern: orient the guest, empower the guest, then hold the guest. The arc does not include excitement or delight, which is appropriate -- Taline's situation is too urgent and too consequential for the platform to pursue positive emotion as a goal. The right emotional output is the absence of negative emotion: no confusion, no rejection, no helplessness, no anxiety. This is a 'remove the pain' arc, not an 'add the joy' arc, and it is the correct choice for a guest under life-level pressure.

evaluation.note: This run uses guest journey phases (listing_evaluation, not evaluation). See listing_evaluation below.

onboarding.note: Guest onboarding is not a distinct phase in the guest journey type used by this lens.

listing_creation.note: Guest journey does not include listing_creation.

pricing.note: Guest pricing is covered under listing_evaluation and proposal_creation. See those phases.

proposal_mgmt.note: Guest proposal management is covered under proposal_creation. See that phase.

retention.note: Guest retention is not addressed by this lens. The call ends before any booking occurs.

search.note: Guest-specific phase not in default coverage map.

listing_evaluation.note: Guest-specific phase. Highest coverage because this is where the category mismatch, pricing opacity, and adaptation all converge.

acceptance.note: Guest-specific phase. Thinner coverage because Taline's call did not reach acceptance -- elements are projected.

move_in.note: Guest-specific phase. Coverage is thin because Taline's call is entirely pre-booking.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The works layer identified 6 process patterns but all are pre-booking. The active lease phase for a guest with Taline's profile (rigid M-F pattern, childcare constraints, zero margin for error) likely contains process patterns around schedule disruption handling, date change friction, and weekly transition logistics. A future lens targeting an active guest would fill this gap.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: A guest call transcript from someone in an active Split Lease arrangement, ideally one who has experienced a schedule disruption or date change, paired with a book on routine design or habit formation.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The looks layer produced 7 visual patterns, all well-grounded in the token system. However, none address the mobile-first context: Taline was calling while driving in traffic (0:35). The visual patterns assume a screen-based interaction context. A future pass should define how these components adapt to low-attention, small-screen, possibly voice-first contexts.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Mobile interaction research or a book on designing for divided attention. The mobile versions of the calendar builder, bridge card, and status tracker need specific visual specifications.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The feels layer produced 7 emotional elements with a coherent arc (calm -> relief -> confidence -> safety). But the arc does not address the emotional experience of the host-guest relationship -- what Taline feels about Bryant as an intermediary, what trust she extends or withholds from the platform through the agent. The emotional dynamics of intermediary trust are unexplored.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: A guest call where the guest has more direct interaction with the host (not just the agent), paired with a book on trust dynamics in mediated relationships. The emotional arc may need a 'trust in intermediary' element between confidence and safety.
